General Competencies.text: Working as an effective team member.
General Competencies.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢	Responsibilities of Apprentice to Sponsor | Saw Filer 1, 1-2-5 to 1-2-6
‚Ä¢	Saw Filer Duties and Team Coordination | Saw Filer 1, 1-1-2
‚Ä¢	Filing Room Role in Shift Continuity | Saw Filer 1, 1-2-4
General Competencies.what: A saw filer is part of a larger production team that includes supervisors, millwrights, operators, electricians, and fellow filers across different shifts. Being an effective team member means maintaining clear communication, supporting smooth shift transitions, working collaboratively, and upholding shared shop responsibilities. It also includes fulfilling your duties to your sponsor and actively participating in your apprenticeship obligations.
General Competencies.looksLike:
‚Ä¢	You coordinate with the incoming and outgoing filer about the current condition of saws, changes in strain or alignment, upcoming saw changes, and any issues observed during operation.
‚Ä¢	You record all issues or unusual conditions (e.g., vibration, gullet cracks, premature dulling, etc.) in shift logs or communication books, if in use.
‚Ä¢	You follow site-specific communication protocols such as tagging saws, labeling saws as out-of-service, or notifying supervisors when a saw or guide is awaiting repair or setup.
‚Ä¢	You assist other trades, especially millwrights, when removing, installing, or aligning saws‚Äîproviding details like direction of lead, prior setup details, or vibration concerns.
‚Ä¢	You fulfill your obligations to your sponsor by checking in regularly, reviewing progress, and ensuring your hours and logbook entries are up to date.
‚Ä¢	You are present during shift handovers, and you ensure continuity by briefing the next filer on incomplete work, saw setup status, or known troubleshooting.
General Competencies.critical: Filing rooms operate continuously across shifts, and saws are only one component in a multi-step cutting system. If communication breaks down, saws may be installed incorrectly, worn tools may be reused, or safety procedures may be skipped. Miscommunication leads to downtime, unsafe conditions, lumber defects, and avoidable delays in production. Team-based awareness, accurate documentation, and proactive communication are core to the professional standards of a certified filer.

General Competencies.text: Attention to detail and ability to focus.
General Competencies.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢	Importance of Saw Flatness, Tension Zones, and Inspection Accuracy
Saw Filer 1, Section 3-2-1 to 3-2-3
‚Ä¢	Crack Inspection and Tolerance Limits
Saw Filer 1, Section 6-8-2
‚Ä¢	Bench Work and Quality Inspection Expectations
Saw Filer 1, Section 7-1-1
‚Ä¢	Saw Flatness Maximum Deviation: 0.002‚Äù
Saw Filer 1, Section 13-1-1
General Competencies.what:
Precision is the cornerstone of all filing work. A journeyperson saw filer is expected to maintain microscopic accuracy during measurement, inspection, welding, grinding, and alignment procedures. This competency also requires sustained mental focus, even during repetitive or late-shift tasks. Attention to detail is not optional‚Äîit is a safety requirement. You must catch variations as small as 0.002" and respond with the correct technique and tool.
üìè Flatness tolerances under 0.002" are used when inspecting for saw dish. Even a dish of 0.002" must be corrected before tensioning.
üìö Saw Filer 1, Section 13-1-1
General Competencies.looksLike:
‚Ä¢        When leveling a saw, you detect and correct a 0.002" dish using a certified straightedge and correct hammering technique.
‚Ä¢        During tensioning, you observe the symmetry and integrity of the tension ring using proper back gauge placement and drop test verification, ensuring uniformity before any saw is cleared for service.
‚Ä¢        When using a micrometer or dial indicator, you:
o        Double-check readings for consistency
o        Clean both the saw surface and the measuring tool
o        Confirm tool calibration or report immediately if suspect
‚Ä¢        During blade inspections, you maintain full focus‚Äîeven when inspecting the third or fourth band of a shift‚Äîto ensure:
o        No gullet cracks, heat tint, or metal fatigue is missed
o        The saw body shows no signs of warping, twist, or abnormal wear
‚Ä¢        When regrinding a tooth, you:
o        Compare the result directly to a known-good profile
o        Use templates and cam settings to confirm accuracy rather than assuming angles are correct
General Competencies.critical:
The filing trade deals in thousandths of an inch. A misaligned saw, under-tensioned plate, or grind angle off by even 1¬∞ can cause:
‚Ä¢	Blade wobble, snaking, or cracking
‚Ä¢	Excess heat and gullet fatigue
‚Ä¢	Misaligned cuts or lumber defects
‚Ä¢	Damage to bearings, guides, or collars
‚Ä¢	Personal injury from ejected parts or unexpected failure
Your vigilance prevents cascading errors that can cause downtime, reduce tool life, and compromise safety. A saw that ‚Äúlooks fine‚Äù may still fail at 10,000 FPM. You are the final line of defense.

General Competencies.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢	Apprentice Responsibilities and Mentor Interaction
Saw Filer 1, Sections 1-2-4 to 1-2-6
‚Ä¢	Importance of Hands-on Learning and Self-tracking
Saw Filer 1, Section 1-2-3
General Competencies.what:
üîß What this means:
Apprenticeship in the saw trades is not passive‚Äîit requires full engagement in both hands-on and technical learning. You are expected to take ownership of your development by staying involved in every aspect of the training process. This means participating actively in shop tasks, seeking clarification when needed, and tracking your skill progression using the ETA 671 Work Process Schedule (Saw Filer Competency Log).
Your mentor plays a critical role in shaping your training‚Äîbut it is your responsibility to follow through, ask questions, and pursue improvement. Filing is learned by doing, and every task you complete should move you closer to becoming a safe, skilled tradesperson.
General Competencies.looksLike:
‚Ä¢	You bring your ETA 671 Work Process Schedule (Saw Filer Competency Log) to evaluations and:
o	Ensure entries are up to date with clear descriptions of completed tasks
o	Obtain proper sign-off from your mentor based on direct observation
o	Use the log to guide what skills you still need exposure to
‚Ä¢	You engage your mentor with relevant, job-specific questions, such as:
o	‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the best way to check for tight zones in this tension ring?‚Äù
o	‚ÄúShould I swage before or after confirming kerf width with the gauge?‚Äù
o	‚ÄúIs this crown profile correct for the feed rate we‚Äôre running?‚Äù
‚Ä¢	You request to repeat high-skill procedures or shadow others performing them, including:
o	Crack welding and annealing
o	Tensioning with stretcher rolls
o	Knife balancing and babbitting
o	Swaging and shaping under species-specific tolerances
‚Ä¢	You take responsibility for your classroom learning by:
o	Registering for technical training well in advance
o	Coordinating your schedule with your mentor and supervisor
o	Bringing current shop experiences and questions into the classroom for discussion
‚Ä¢	You actively track your hours and performance, using your log to:
o	Identify weak areas or incomplete competencies
o	Measure progress toward certification goals
o	Organize questions and tasks for review with your mentor
General Competencies.critical:
Saw filing cannot be learned by standing and watching. Many of the most important skills‚Äîtensioning, leveling, grinding geometry, safe handling‚Äîrequire hundreds of repetitions to master. Apprentices who do not ask questions or seek out new tasks tend to fall behind or develop unsafe habits. A passive approach delays your certification and places the burden on your mentor to chase your development.
In contrast, a filer who participates actively builds:
‚Ä¢	Technical confidence
‚Ä¢	Reliable habits under pressure
‚Ä¢	A complete training record
‚Ä¢	Trust and credibility with their team
If you don‚Äôt ask, you don‚Äôt learn.

General Competencies.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢	Filing Room Collaboration and Process Improvement
Saw Filer 1, Section 1-2-4
‚Ä¢	Communication with Other Trades and Team Roles
Saw Filer 1, Sections 1-2-5 to 1-2-6
General Competencies.what:
A skilled filer is not only a technician but a problem solver and contributor to shop improvement. Sharing ideas means voicing observations that can prevent damage, reduce waste, improve workflow, or enhance safety. Whether it's a small adjustment to a tagging system or a technical insight about guide pressure, your input helps optimize the operation. This is especially important during shift changes, saw troubleshooting, or when testing new setups.
As a professional, your role includes offering constructive, evidence-based suggestions, regardless of your level of experience. Apprentices who speak up respectfully build trust and show a genuine commitment to the trade.
General Competencies.looksLike:
‚Ä¢        You identify that a grinding wheel is wearing unevenly, and recommend replacement before it causes improper tooth geometry, excessive heat, or vibration.
‚Ä¢        You notice that the saw storage rack has bent hooks, and explain how it could warp saws, recommending realignment or replacement.
‚Ä¢        You suggest introducing a visual tagging system using magnets, flags, or color codes to clearly mark:
o        Saws that are tensioned and ready
o        Saws awaiting weld inspection
o        Saws tagged out due to damage or imbalance
‚Ä¢        You observe that increasing table travel speed during knife grinding reduced heat tint, and demonstrate the result to your mentor or crew.
‚Ä¢        You report a recurring issue on the edger, pointing out that guide bolts may be backing off or misaligned‚Äîprompting an adjustment that prevents further defects.
‚Ä¢        During a team install, you suggest reviewing back gauge measurements due to unexpected tracking on the previous shift‚Äîleading to correction of a strain offset.
These are just a few examples.
General Competencies.critical:
‚ùó Why this is critical:
Filers are closest to the tools, the saws, and the real-time issues that impact performance and safety. No one sees everything, and a single overlooked issue‚Äîlike a dull grinder, untagged saw, or guide slip‚Äîcan lead to:
‚Ä¢	Unsafe equipment being reinstalled
‚Ä¢	Wasted lumber or machine damage
‚Ä¢	Excess vibration, bearing failure, or saw ejection
‚Ä¢	Loss of time and credibility across shifts
Shops that welcome suggestions run smarter and safer. By sharing your ideas, you:
‚Ä¢	Build trust with your mentor and coworkers
‚Ä¢	Reinforce a culture of accountability
‚Ä¢	Help prevent breakdowns before they happen
‚Ä¢	Show leadership in your approach to filing

Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢	Personal Apparel & Safety Equipment
Saw Filer 1, Sections 2-1-1 to 2-1-12
‚Ä¢	Knife Safety & Glove Standards
Saw Filer 1, Sections 8-1-1 to 8-1-2
‚Ä¢	Hearing Protection Requirements
Saw Filer 1, Section 2-1-7
Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.what:
Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is not just a company policy‚Äîit‚Äôs a legal requirement and a critical barrier between you and high-risk hazards in the filing room. Grinders, wheels, compressed air, heavy saws, and knife handling all expose you to sharp edges, fast-moving machinery, flying debris, and noise. Wearing the correct PPE at all times reduces the risk of permanent injury, even death.
PPE is job-specific. You must know which PPE applies to which task and wear it every time‚Äînot just when reminded.
Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.looksLike:
‚Ä¢	You wear CSA-approved safety glasses or a full face shield:
o	When grinding saws, dressing wheels, or cleaning with compressed air
o	Any time you‚Äôre exposed to sparks, debris, or flying grit
‚Ä¢	You wear grip-rated gloves (rubberized or cloth with friction surface):
o	When handling chipper knives, especially when oily or wet
o	You avoid leather gloves for knives‚Äîthey become slippery and dangerous when wet
‚Ä¢	You use hearing protection:
o	In all zones rated over 85 dB, with a preference for NRR 25 or higher in chainsaw and grinder areas
o	You keep extra pairs accessible and stored in clean cases
‚Ä¢	When working at height (e.g., lowering circular saws from an overhead rack), you:
o	Use a fall restraint system rated for 5,000 lbs
o	Ensure your lanyard and snap hooks are anchored properly before beginning the lift
‚Ä¢	You do not wear:
o	Loose clothing or untied coveralls
o	Jewelry, chains, or rings
o	Unrestrained long hair around moving tools or shaft-driven machinery
Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.critical:
Saw shops are high-risk environments. Grinders can explode, saws can spring back, knives can slip, and contact with rotating equipment can lead to:
‚Ä¢	Lacerations
‚Ä¢	Eye injuries or blindness
‚Ä¢	Crushed fingers or broken bones
‚Ä¢	Hearing loss
‚Ä¢	Fatal entanglement injuries
PPE is your first line of defense, but only if used consistently and correctly. It must also be maintained, inspected, and fitted properly to be effective

Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.text: Demonstrate safe handling of knives and saws.
Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢	Knife Handling & Cart Use
Saw Filer 1, Sections 8-1-1 to 8-1-2
‚Ä¢	Circular Saw Handling Procedures
Saw Filer 2, Section 9-1-2
‚Ä¢	Saw Disposal Rules
Saw Filer 1, Section 2-2-13
Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.what:
Saws and knives are sharp, heavy, and under mechanical stress. Improper handling‚Äîeven for a few seconds‚Äîcan result in serious lacerations, back injuries, or permanent disability. Safe handling includes lifting, transporting, flipping, and disposing of all blades according to your site‚Äôs safety policies and the instructions outlined in the Saw Filer 1 training guide.
This competency ensures you handle every blade with respect, using proper technique, safe tools, and full awareness of your surroundings. There are no shortcuts when it comes to moving sharp steel.
Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.looksLike:
‚Ä¢        You handle one chipper knife at a time, always using:
o        Approved knife carts or knife boxes in good condition
o        Secure lids and handles when transporting between stations
‚Ä¢        When flipping a bandsaw, you:
o        Stand on the non-tooth (back) side
o        Use both hands with clear communication if working with a partner
o        Ensure there‚Äôs adequate room‚Äîno flips near grinders, walls, or machinery
‚Ä¢        You never carry multiple saws by hand:
o        You use a cart or hoist system for bandsaws and circular saws
o        You ensure the weight is balanced and the path is clear
‚Ä¢        When handling large circular saws (250+ lbs):
o        You inspect all hoisting gear first (hooks, slings, chains, anchors)
o        You follow a Job Safety Analysis (JSA) if your site requires one for overhead or crane lifts
‚Ä¢        For disposal of worn saws:
o        You do not coil bandsaws for disposal due to spring hazard
o	Instead, cut them into short segments and place them in designated steel disposal bins
Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.critical:
‚ùó Why this is critical:
Saws and knives are designed to cut wood at thousands of feet per minute‚Äîand they don‚Äôt know the difference between wood and skin. Injuries from saw handling include:
‚Ä¢	Deep cuts or amputations from sharp edges
‚Ä¢	Strained backs or shoulders from improper lifting
‚Ä¢	Crushed toes from dropped circulars or racks
‚Ä¢	Head and eye injuries from springing or coiling saws
Improper handling also leads to damaged saws‚Äîa bent band or dropped plate may become unusable or dangerous in operation. This creates costly downtime, poor cutting performance, and serious safety concerns for others on the team.

Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢	Grinder and Tool Safety
Saw Filer 1, Sections 2-1-10 to 2-1-12
‚Ä¢	Lockout & Energy Isolation Procedures
Saw Filer 1, Section 2-1-8
Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.what:
Proper use of saw shop equipment is about more than just knowing how to turn on a grinder‚Äîit‚Äôs about respecting safety systems, following lockout protocols, and operating each machine within its safe parameters. Every piece of equipment in the filing room‚Äîfrom grinders to welders to chipper heads‚Äîcomes with mechanical risks. Misuse can result in injury, equipment damage, or incorrect saw geometry that leads to catastrophic saw failure in the mill.
This competency demands that you never bypass safeguards, always verify machine readiness, and match your tools to the job and material type.
Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.looksLike:
‚Ä¢	You never bypass or disable:
o	Grinder guards, hoods, or shields
o	Emergency stop buttons
o	Interlocks or limit switches on filing room machines
‚Ä¢	You always follow lockout/tagout procedures before servicing equipment:
o	Apply your personal lock on both electrical and mechanical isolation points
o	Test for zero energy before beginning service
o	Ensure no other personnel can accidentally re-energize the system
‚Ä¢	Before operating a grinder, you:
o	Inspect the grinding wheel for cracks, glazing, or uneven wear
o	Confirm that the wheel speed rating (RPM) matches or exceeds the grinder‚Äôs rated speed
o	Check that the wheel is mounted with correct flange pressure and without overtightening
‚Ä¢	You confirm safe operation of power and pneumatic tools by:
o	Checking cords and hoses for splits, kinks, or leaks
o	Testing switches and emergency shutoffs
o	Verifying that tool mounts, clamps, and guards are secure
‚Ä¢	When using a drill press, grinder, or machining tool:
o	You never hold parts by hand
o	You always use vises, clamps, or fixtures rated for the task
o	You wear appropriate PPE and secure long sleeves or hair to prevent entanglement
Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.critical:
The vast majority of shop injuries and equipment failures occur when:
‚Ä¢	Safety guards are removed
‚Ä¢	Lockout procedures are skipped
‚Ä¢	Untrained users operate high-speed equipment without inspection
Improper tool usage can:
‚Ä¢	Send grinding wheels flying apart at 9,000+ RPM
‚Ä¢	Crack saw plate due to overheating or incorrect tension
‚Ä¢	Cause fires from overheated motors or coolant leaks
‚Ä¢	Result in cuts, crushes, or amputations from entanglement or tool recoil
Respecting every piece of equipment in the shop‚Äîand its built-in safety systems‚Äîis non-negotiable. A moment‚Äôs inattention can lead to permanent injury or a damaged saw that fails in the mill under load.

Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.text: Properly store and maintain equipment and tools.
Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢	Tool Storage and Handling
Saw Filer 1, Sections 2-1-9 to 2-1-11
‚Ä¢	Knife & Saw Storage Practices
Saw Filer 1, Section 2-2-13
Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.what:
üîß What this means:
Filing tools are high-precision instruments that require proper care, storage, and routine maintenance to remain accurate and safe to use. When tools like micrometers, tension gauges, files, and saw dressing tools are mishandled or stored incorrectly, they lose calibration, become contaminated, or fail without warning. Tool storage and care is not just about tidiness‚Äîit‚Äôs about maintaining filing accuracy, protecting your safety, and extending the life of both hand tools and heavy equipment.
You‚Äôre responsible for ensuring every tool you use is:
‚Ä¢	Clean
‚Ä¢	Accurate
‚Ä¢	Stored in the correct location
‚Ä¢	Free from damage
Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.looksLike:
‚Ä¢	You return all hand tools to labeled drawers, foam-lined cases, or shadow boards after use:
o	You never leave files, hammers, or measuring tools on benches, saw carts, or grinder housings
‚Ä¢	You store measuring instruments (micrometers, dial indicators, back gauges) in:
o	Foam-lined or cushioned containers
o	Dry and sealed locations free from dust and temperature extremes
‚Ä¢	You maintain cutting tools (e.g., chisels, files, stones) by:
o	Keeping them oiled, dressed, and stored with edge protection
o	Reporting and tagging any cracked handles, burrs, or mushroomed heads
‚Ä¢	You use tool-specific storage systems, including:
o	Cardboard or leather file sleeves
o	Knife trays with individual slots
o	Divider bins for swaging dies and shaping cams
‚Ä¢	You do not mix layout and striking tools in drawers with precision equipment
‚Ä¢	You ensure coolant systems, grinders, and tensioning tools are:
o	Cleaned at the end of each shift
o	Logged for maintenance if vibration, play, or imbalance is detected
o	Lubricated and calibrated on the schedule set by your shop or mentor
Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.critical:
A damaged tool makes damaged saws. When filing tools are left dirty, dented, or out of alignment:
‚Ä¢	You lose measurement accuracy
‚Ä¢	Your tension or leveling work is flawed
‚Ä¢	Grinders run unbalanced, producing heat damage or incorrect tooth geometry
‚Ä¢	Sharp edges left exposed can cut you or your co-workers during routine shop movement
Proper tool storage and care ensures:
‚Ä¢	Faster, safer workflows
‚Ä¢	Better communication between shifts
‚Ä¢	Maximum tool life
‚Ä¢	Consistency in saw performance and safety inspections
It also shows professionalism and pride in your work‚Äîtwo traits expected of every certified saw filer.

Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢	Filing Room Housekeeping Rules
Saw Filer 1, Section 2-1-1
‚Ä¢	Cleaning Protocols & Safe Surfaces
Saw Filer 1, Sections 2-1-9 to 2-1-12
Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.what:
A clean and organized filing room is not just a sign of professionalism‚Äîit‚Äôs a critical component of shop safety, workflow efficiency, and tool accountability. Saw filing environments involve metal shavings, grinding dust, oils, solvents, and sharp tools. Without proper housekeeping, these materials create slip hazards, fire risks, tool damage, and lost time. This competency involves understanding how and when to clean, what to clean with, and maintaining shared areas to prevent hazards before they occur.
Filing is a trade of precision‚Äîyour bench and work habits should reflect that precision.
Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.looksLike:
‚Ä¢	You sweep or vacuum your workstation, grinder area, and babbitting station after each task‚Äînot just at the end of shift
o	You remove filings, gullet dust, and coolant residue that can interfere with measurement and inspection
‚Ä¢	You dispose of rags used with oil, solvent, or flammable material in fire-rated bins with self-closing lids
o	You report spills immediately‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs oil, coolant, or grinding slurry‚Äîand use absorbent pads or spill kits
‚Ä¢	You keep all walkways, platforms, and saw carts free of debris:
o	No hoses, tools, or personal items are left in traffic zones
o	You tuck cords away or secure them overhead where applicable
‚Ä¢	You store sharp tools with guards or in trays‚Äînot on benches or carts where others can contact them unexpectedly
o	This includes files, tooth gauges, swaging dies, and scrap saws
‚Ä¢	You regularly clean:
o	Bench surfaces and toolboxes
o	Tensioning equipment and measurement stations
o	Coolant tanks, filter screens, and waste trays
‚Ä¢	You reset shared work areas after use:
o	Tools are returned
o	Labels are clear
o	Blades are either tagged or ready for service
Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.critical:
Filing rooms contain flammable materials, sharp objects, hot metals, and high-speed tools. Poor housekeeping creates:
‚Ä¢	Slips, trips, and falls from coolant, rags, or grinding dust
‚Ä¢	Cuts or punctures from exposed sharp tools
‚Ä¢	Fire hazards from oil-soaked rags left on benches
‚Ä¢	Tool loss and miscommunication across shifts
‚Ä¢	Time wasted locating tools or cleaning up after others
Proper housekeeping ensures that your safety, saw quality, and work efficiency remain intact. It also shows professionalism and respect for your crew‚Äîtwo qualities that define the top filers in the trade

Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢	Babbitt Safety Procedures and PPE
Saw Filer 1, Sections 2-1-1, 2-1-9
‚Ä¢	Lead Handling and Molten Metal Pouring
Saw Filer 1, Section 9-6-3
Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.what:
Babbitting involves pouring molten metal at temperatures often exceeding 600¬∞F (315¬∞C) to create bearing surfaces. This is one of the most hazardous tasks in saw maintenance due to the risks of splash burns, inhalation of lead fumes, and explosive reactions with moisture. Safe babbitting requires full PPE, properly maintained equipment, and strict control over temperature, ventilation, and cleanliness.
The goal is to produce precise, defect-free babbitt surfaces‚Äîwithout exposing yourself or others to unnecessary danger.
Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.looksLike:
‚Ä¢	You inspect the pouring area for:
o	Dry surfaces (no moisture on molds or equipment)
o	Clean workspace with no rags, sawdust, or oil nearby
o	Properly secured ladles and holders
‚Ä¢	You wear all required PPE:
o	Face shield over safety glasses
o	Heat-resistant gloves rated for molten metal
o	Flame-resistant coveralls or apron
o	Respirator when using lead-based or zinc-based babbitt in poorly ventilated areas
‚Ä¢	You preheat molds and parts to avoid steam explosions:
o	Use a torch or oven to bring molds to safe casting temperature
o	You never pour molten babbitt into cold or wet parts
‚Ä¢	You control pouring temperature using a thermometer:
o	Target range is 475¬∞F‚Äì625¬∞F, depending on alloy
o	You skim off dross (oxidized impurities) before pouring
‚Ä¢	After pouring:
o	You allow parts to cool under supervision
o	You clean up any spills using proper disposal methods
o	You never quench hot babbitt in water or oil
Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.critical:
Improper babbitting causes:
‚Ä¢	Burns and flash injuries from molten metal splash
‚Ä¢	Toxic fume inhalation, especially from lead- or cadmium-containing alloys
‚Ä¢	Explosive reactions if poured into moist surfaces
‚Ä¢	Cracked, porous, or delaminated bearings that fail under load
Good babbitt work produces safe, clean bearing fits and guide pads. Unsafe babbitt handling endangers you, your crew, and the shop.

Demonstrate Safe Work Practices.text: Knife and chipper safety (access and replacement of components).

Quality Control.text: Explain proper tools to use for saw measurement
Quality Control.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Measuring Tool Use and Selection
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 3-2-1
‚Ä¢ Precision Tool Care and Inspection
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Sections 3-2-2 to 3-2-3
Quality Control.what:
Precision measurement is foundational to every step of the saw filing process. You are expected to understand which tool to use for each type of measurement‚Äîwhether checking plate thickness, saw flatness, tension ring placement, or gullet geometry. Each tool must be suited to the job, properly maintained, and handled with care to produce consistent, reliable readings.
The ability to select the correct measuring tool‚Äîand know its limitations‚Äîensures accuracy in leveling, tensioning, grinding, and inspection.
Quality Control.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ You select and use the following tools for specific saw measurements:
‚Ä¢	Straightedge: to detect saw dish or twist during benching
‚Ä¢	Tension gauge: to measure drop inside and outside of tension ring
‚Ä¢	Back gauge: to evaluate tension shape and concentricity along the back
‚Ä¢	Feeler gauges: to assess side clearance or knife-to-anvil spacing
‚Ä¢	Micrometer or calipers: to verify plate thickness and saw body consistency
‚Ä¢	Dial indicator: to measure runout, collar wobble, or arbor alignment
‚Ä¢ You inspect your tools before use:
‚Ä¢	Ensure tools are clean and dry
‚Ä¢	Confirm zero setting on gauges and micrometers
‚Ä¢	Check for bent edges, cracked faces, or debris in tool joints
‚Ä¢ You handle tools properly:
‚Ä¢	Place precision instruments only on clean, stable surfaces
‚Ä¢	Store them in protective cases after each use
‚Ä¢	Never mix layout or impact tools (e.g., files or hammers) with precision gauges
Quality Control.critical:
Incorrect or poorly chosen measurement tools lead to: ‚Ä¢ Misaligned saw tension zones ‚Ä¢ Improper lead or dish corrections ‚Ä¢ Cracked saws caused by hidden stress or deformation ‚Ä¢ Out-of-spec lumber and unplanned downtime
Saw filers are judged not just by their hammer work‚Äîbut by the accuracy of their setup and inspections. If your measuring tools aren‚Äôt correct, every adjustment you make could be wrong.

Quality Control.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Measuring and Inspection Technique
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 3-2-2
‚Ä¢ Tool Handling Best Practices
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 3-2-3
Quality Control.what:
üîß What this means:
Knowing which tool to use is only part of the job‚Äîa saw filer must also demonstrate precise technique when using any measuring instrument. This includes proper hand positioning, consistent pressure, correct angle of application, and an understanding of when environmental conditions (like heat, oil, or light) might skew results.
Measuring technique is about repeatability and accuracy. Every cut, grind, or tensioning step that follows a measurement is only as good as the technique used to obtain it.
Quality Control.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ You take time to ensure surfaces are clean and free of oil, pitch, or burrs before measuring.
‚Ä¢ You use a straightedge by:
‚Ä¢	Holding it perpendicular to the saw plate
‚Ä¢	Backlighting with proper angle and contrast to detect rise or dish
‚Ä¢	Confirming against a calibrated reference before use
‚Ä¢ When using a micrometer or caliper, you:
‚Ä¢	Set zero against a known reference block
‚Ä¢	Apply consistent, light pressure to avoid deforming thin saw steel
‚Ä¢	Measure multiple points on the saw (e.g., near collar line, mid-body, and tension ring)
‚Ä¢ When using a dial indicator or tension gauge, you:
‚Ä¢	Ensure proper tool seating and no side loading
‚Ä¢	Zero the dial before starting
‚Ä¢	Record readings methodically across the plate to assess symmetry
‚Ä¢ You log or report all measurements clearly and accurately:
‚Ä¢	No rounding of tension drop values
‚Ä¢	Dish readings (e.g., ‚Äú0.002‚Äù concave‚Äù) must reflect maximum observed variation
‚Ä¢ You maintain focus, especially when repeating a task multiple times (e.g., checking the third bandsaw of the shift):
‚Ä¢	You inspect each tooth, gullet, or zone individually‚Äîwithout assumptions
Quality Control.critical:
Improper measuring technique leads to improper saw performance. Even if the tool is accurate, poor technique results in: ‚Ä¢ Incorrect tension or leveling corrections ‚Ä¢ Faulty grind angles that damage tooth strength ‚Ä¢ Misaligned saws leading to gullet cracking or vibration ‚Ä¢ Untraceable dimensional errors in the lumber
Saw shops that maintain high standards of measurement:
‚Ä¢	Prevent injuries from cracked or failed saws
‚Ä¢	Deliver higher lumber recovery rates
‚Ä¢	Build confidence across shift teams and mill supervisors
You are expected to treat each reading as a precision action, not a guess.

Quality Control.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Grinder and Tool Safety
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Sections 2-1-10 to 2-1-12
‚Ä¢ Lockout and Equipment Inspection
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 2-1-8
‚Ä¢ Measuring and Testing Setup
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Sections 3-2-1 to 3-2-3
Quality Control.what:
Utilizing shop equipment correctly is a core part of your responsibility as a saw filer. It‚Äôs not enough to simply operate a grinder, tension gauge, or measuring stand‚Äîyou must demonstrate that you understand machine compatibility, setup requirements, and safety limitations.
Proper utilization means using machines within their specifications, performing routine checks before use, and following lockout procedures when necessary. This applies to all measuring, tensioning, and grinding equipment used in saw inspection and setup.
Quality Control.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ You confirm that all equipment is clean, functional, and calibrated before use:
‚Ä¢	Grinder wheels are trued, balanced, and suitable for material (e.g., vitrified vs. CBN)
‚Ä¢	Dial indicators and gauges are zeroed and seated properly
‚Ä¢	Straightedges are free from warping or nicks
‚Ä¢ Before using powered tools or grinders, you:
‚Ä¢	Verify the RPM rating on grinding wheels matches the machine (e.g., max wheel speed < grinder speed)
‚Ä¢	Confirm guards, shields, and splash hoods are in place and secure
‚Ä¢	Conduct a visual and tactile inspection for:
o	Vibration or bearing play
o	Loose mounts or shifting guides
o	Cracks in wheels, arbors, or safety shields
‚Ä¢ You follow proper lockout/tagout when servicing or adjusting equipment:
‚Ä¢	Use your personal lock
‚Ä¢	Test for zero energy before beginning
‚Ä¢	Confirm all moving components are secured before resuming operation
‚Ä¢ You ensure precision tools are used with compatible fixtures:
‚Ä¢	Back gauges sit flush and square on the plate
‚Ä¢	Indicators are mounted to stable bases, not handheld or makeshift jigs
‚Ä¢ You report or tag out any machine that:
‚Ä¢	Vibrates excessively
‚Ä¢	Produces irregular finishes
‚Ä¢	Shows signs of mechanical wear or electrical failure
Quality Control.critical:
Incorrect use of shop equipment can result in: ‚Ä¢ Grinder explosions or wheel fragmentation ‚Ä¢ Undetected tension or runout due to unstable measuring setups ‚Ä¢ Collapsed bearings or arbor failures in circular saws ‚Ä¢ Cuts, burns, or caught-hand injuries from bypassed guards
Proper machine utilization is non-negotiable. It ensures:
‚Ä¢	Repeatable tension and leveling results
‚Ä¢	Accurate tooth and plate geometry
‚Ä¢	A safe working environment for you and your crew

Quality Control.text: Properly store and maintain equipment and tools
Quality Control.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Tool Storage and Handling
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Sections 2-1-9 to 2-1-11
‚Ä¢ Precision Tool Maintenance
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 3-2-2
Quality Control.what:
Precision tools must be protected from contamination, mechanical shock, and moisture. Proper storage and maintenance ensures your instruments remain accurate and safe, and helps prevent accidental injuries or calibration drift.
As a filer, you‚Äôre expected to store and maintain everything from micrometers and back gauges to grinding wheels, hammers, and dial indicators in a clean, organized, and well-documented manner.
Quality Control.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ You return all tools to their assigned storage after each task:
‚Ä¢	Micrometers and calipers go in foam-lined, sealed cases
‚Ä¢	Files are stored in sleeves or dividers‚Äînever mixed with hammers or layout tools
‚Ä¢	Knives are stored with edges protected, using trays or guards
‚Ä¢ You perform routine maintenance:
‚Ä¢	Lightly oil exposed steel surfaces on back gauges, indicators, and feeler blades
‚Ä¢	Clean threads on micrometers and dial stems using a soft brush
‚Ä¢	Dress and balance grinding wheels regularly and inspect for cracks or glazing
‚Ä¢ You never drop, force, or jam tools into drawers or bins
‚Ä¢ You inspect tool condition before and after each use:
‚Ä¢	Straightedges checked for dents or edge burrs
‚Ä¢	Calipers verified for zero reset
‚Ä¢	Handles, tool heads, and dials confirmed secure and intact
‚Ä¢ You tag out any tool that gives inconsistent readings, won‚Äôt zero, or shows mechanical damage
Quality Control.critical:
‚ùó Why this is critical:
Improper tool care leads to: ‚Ä¢ Inaccurate saw setup and failed inspections
‚Ä¢ Tool failure or unsafe operation (e.g., wheel shatter, micrometer jamming)
‚Ä¢ Increased wear on saw blades from misread tolerances
‚Ä¢ Injuries caused by exposed sharp edges or dropped heavy tools
Clean, well-maintained tools = clean, high-performing saws. Your habits with tool care directly reflect your commitment to safety, accuracy, and professionalism.

Quality Control.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Knife-to-Anvil Clearance & Adjustments
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Sections 8-1-7 to 8-1-9
‚Ä¢ Saw Side Clearance and Setup
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 4-8-1
‚Ä¢ Kerf and Clearance Calculations
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 4-8-2
Quality Control.what:
Clearance refers to the precise space between the cutting tooth or knife and surrounding elements such as the workpiece, anvil, or guide. Setting the correct clearance ensures:
‚Ä¢        Free chip flow
‚Ä¢        Reduced heat and friction
‚Ä¢        Accurate cutting performance
‚Ä¢        Saw longevity and safety
As a filer, you must understand clearance standards across band saws, circular saws, and chippers‚Äîand be able to explain how clearance values change with species, saw gauge, and cutting conditions (e.g., frozen vs. green wood).
Quality Control.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ For chipper knives:
‚Ä¢	You measure knife-to-anvil clearance using a feeler gauge
‚Ä¢	The target range is typically 0.030"‚Äì0.060", depending on machine and wood species
‚Ä¢	You adjust knife projection by changing shim thickness or backing screws, ensuring consistency across all knives
‚Ä¢ For saws:
‚Ä¢	You calculate total kerf (cut width) using the formula:
Kerf = plate thickness + (2 √ó side clearance)
‚Ä¢	You verify side clearance with a micrometer or feeler gauge at the tooth tip
‚Ä¢	You confirm that clearance is symmetrical (left and right) and within spec for the saw's design
‚Ä¢ During saw service or reshaping:
‚Ä¢	You apply swaging or tipping to restore proper kerf and clearance
‚Ä¢	You shape teeth to maintain radial and tangential clearance, especially in swaged bands
‚Ä¢ You consult mill specifications or species-specific guidelines to select correct clearance values based on:
‚Ä¢	Wood density (e.g., hardwood vs. softwood)
‚Ä¢	Moisture content (e.g., frozen or kiln-dried stock)
‚Ä¢	Desired lumber finish
Quality Control.critical:
Improper clearance is one of the most common causes of: ‚Ä¢ Overheating and saw wander
‚Ä¢ Gullet cracking or plate distortion
‚Ä¢ Jammed chippers and miscut lumber
‚Ä¢ Guide wear and excessive strain on bearings
Too little clearance causes burning, stalling, and guide damage. Too much causes poor tracking, vibration, and reduced tooth life. Mastery of clearance principles prevents these failures and supports smooth mill operation.

Quality Control.text: Perform calculations to achieve targeted lumber sizes
Quality Control.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Kerf, Bite, and Rim Speed Calculations
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 4-8-1 to 4-8-2
‚Ä¢ Application of Feed and Speed Data
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 3-1-18
Quality Control.what:
Filers play a key role in ensuring that saws produce accurate lumber sizes. This involves understanding and applying formulas related to tooth bite, rim speed, kerf, and feed speed. You must be able to calculate values that affect chip formation, saw loading, and final lumber dimensions‚Äîand verify that these are within acceptable production tolerances.
Your calculations inform machine setup and help identify performance issues during operation.
Quality Control.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ You use key formulas such as:
Tooth Bite = Feed Speed (FPM) √∑ (RPM √ó Number of Teeth)
‚Ä¢	Used to determine feed per tooth (ideal chip size)
Tooth Pitch = (Saw Diameter √ó œÄ) √∑ Number of Teeth
‚Ä¢	Used to calculate spacing and support gullets
Rim Speed = (Saw Diameter √ó œÄ √ó RPM) √∑ 12
‚Ä¢	Used to ensure correct cutting speed for material type
‚Ä¢ You verify calculations by:
‚Ä¢	Matching feed rate to wood species and chipper spec
‚Ä¢	Adjusting RPM or number of teeth to maintain correct bite
‚Ä¢	Tracking chip formation and comparing it to target dimensions
‚Ä¢ You interpret the results:
‚Ä¢	If tooth bite is too small ‚Üí saw overloads or rubs
‚Ä¢	If too large ‚Üí poor finish, broken teeth, or gullet cracking
‚Ä¢	If kerf does not match machine feed ‚Üí off-size lumber or tracking problems
‚Ä¢ You input these values into your mill documentation, setup forms, or shift logs to guide adjustments and maintain traceability
Quality Control.critical:
Failure to calculate feed and bite properly results in: ‚Ä¢ Undersized or oversize lumber
‚Ä¢ Reduced recovery and mill yield
‚Ä¢ Excessive strain on saws, motors, and chip systems
‚Ä¢ Incorrect troubleshooting when performance issues arise
By performing accurate calculations, you help maintain:
‚Ä¢	Optimal feed rates
‚Ä¢	Accurate lumber sizes
‚Ä¢	Efficient saw loading and chip removal
‚Ä¢	Long-lasting saw performance and safety

Quality Control.text: Explain and demonstrate understanding and application of torque
Quality Control.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Torque Application in Saw Setup
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 9-1-2
‚Ä¢ Fastening Techniques and Safety
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 2-1-10
Quality Control.what:
Torque refers to the amount of rotational force applied to bolts, nuts, and fasteners‚Äîespecially critical when securing saws to arbors, collars, or chipper components. Applying the correct torque ensures tight, even clamping pressure without over-stressing components. You are expected to know:
‚Ä¢	What torque values are required for each fastening task
‚Ä¢	How to apply torque using appropriate tools (e.g., torque wrench or beam-style driver)
‚Ä¢	How torque interacts with component materials, lubricants, and thermal cycling
Quality Control.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ You determine the required torque for a specific application by referencing:
‚Ä¢	Manufacturer‚Äôs spec sheets for arbors, collars, or insert teeth
‚Ä¢	Mill-standard torque charts based on thread size and grade
‚Ä¢ You use a calibrated torque wrench with the appropriate drive size and socket
‚Ä¢ You follow correct torqueing sequence:
‚Ä¢	For circular saw collars, apply torque in a crisscross pattern to prevent warping
‚Ä¢	For insert tooth saws, torque each insert or fastener to its recommended ft-lbs
‚Ä¢ You inspect all threads and contact surfaces before torqueing:
‚Ä¢	Remove debris and oil unless lubrication is required
‚Ä¢	Ensure seating surfaces are flat and burr-free
‚Ä¢ You re-check torque after thermal cycling (for example, after the saw runs hot then cools)
‚Ä¢ You never estimate by hand or guess at torque‚Äîespecially for structural fasteners
Quality Control.critical:
Over-torquing causes: ‚Ä¢ Cracked collars or warped saw plates
‚Ä¢ Bolt stretch, fatigue, and eventual failure
Under-torquing causes: ‚Ä¢ Collar slippage
‚Ä¢ Misaligned saws
‚Ä¢ Tooth ejection in insert systems
‚Ä¢ Unsafe saw installations that can fail under RPM
Understanding torque ensures mechanical integrity, safety, and precise performance from every saw you install.

Quality Control.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Saw Inspection Standards
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Sections 9-1-1 to 9-1-2
‚Ä¢ Crack Limits and Rejection Criteria
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 2-2-1
‚Ä¢ Tension and Back Specifications
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 3-2-1
Quality Control.what:
Every saw must meet defined standards for dimensions, tolerances, materials, and safety criteria. You are expected to:
‚Ä¢	Interpret spec sheets
‚Ä¢	Verify saw condition against known tolerances
‚Ä¢	Explain why certain specifications (e.g. runout, tension ring diameter, side clearance) matter
This applies to bandsaws, circular saws, and chipper knives. Before any saw is placed into service, it must be confirmed to meet or exceed its specification for safe, accurate operation.
Quality Control.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ When receiving a saw (new or resharpened), you verify:
‚Ä¢	Plate thickness and kerf match required size for the cut line
‚Ä¢	Tooth geometry is consistent and suitable for the wood type
‚Ä¢	Tension ring is located correctly for saw diameter and RPM range
‚Ä¢	Back straightness is within 0.002" over 36", using certified straightedge
‚Ä¢	Runout at eye and rim is within allowable tolerance (typically <0.006")
‚Ä¢ You reference industry or mill-standard specs for:
‚Ä¢	Side clearance values
‚Ä¢	Lead and tension values
‚Ä¢	Minimum radius for cracks or weld locations
‚Ä¢ You reject or tag out any saw that:
‚Ä¢	Exceeds crack limits (e.g., 1.5‚Äù in collar zone on 24‚Äì36‚Äù saws)
‚Ä¢	Has eye elongation that prevents secure arbor fit
‚Ä¢	Fails dish or back straightness tests
‚Ä¢ You document specs in service logs, tagging sheets, or shift reports
Quality Control.critical:
A saw that does not meet spec can: ‚Ä¢ Fail under speed due to incorrect tension or collar fit
‚Ä¢ Produce off-size or warped lumber
‚Ä¢ Introduce dangerous vibration or breakage
‚Ä¢ Waste time, damage mill equipment, or cause injury
Your understanding of saw specs ensures every blade put into production is safe, stable, and fit for purpose‚Äîa key responsibility of every qualified filer.

Saw Guides.what: This competency covers the ability to rebuild worn or damaged saw guides‚Äîparticularly babbitted guides‚Äîby removing old metal, repouring or reshaping, and finishing to correct clearance. A well-dressed guide maintains consistent blade support and prevents deflection or heat buildup during operation.
Saw Guides.looksLike:
You strip the old babbitt from a guide block and re-pour fresh babbitt using a ladle, torch, and mold fixture.

You shape the guide face using a guide dresser or file until it matches specified tolerances.

You verify that the contact surfaces are flat and have correct top and side clearance to the blade.
Saw Guides.critical: Worn or uneven guides allow the saw to flex, wander, or dish during cuts. A properly rebuilt guide ensures the saw remains true to its path, reducing vibration, heating, and lumber defects. Rebuilding instead of replacing also supports cost-effective maintenance and longer equipment life.

Saw Guides.text: Properly maintain guides and guide dresser
Rebuild gang and edger saw guides
Measure and test guide thickness and evenness
Safe and proper handling of guides to maintain quality
Properly remove, pour and replace babbitt

Knives and Chippers.text: Demonstrate proper knife grinding and honing
Knives and Chippers.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Grinding Setup and Angles
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Sections 8-2-6 to 8-2-8
‚Ä¢ Honing Procedure and Edge Inspection
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 8-2-7
‚Ä¢ Grinding Defects and Damage
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Sections 8-2-8 to 8-2-11
Knives and Chippers.what:
Knife grinding and honing are precision processes that directly affect chip quality, knife life, and chipper safety. Knives must be ground to the correct bevel angle, using the correct feed rate, coolant flow, and grinding wheel speed. Honing refines the cutting edge, removes wire burrs, and ensures clean shearing action.
Both steps are essential. Grinding without honing leads to premature edge failure. Honing without proper grinding produces weak, short-lived edges.
Knives and Chippers.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ You inspect and clean the knife before grinding:
‚Ä¢	Remove pitch or buildup with a fine oilstone
‚Ä¢	Check for cracks, wear, or bowing
‚Ä¢ You secure the knife to the grinder:
‚Ä¢	Clamp knives 10‚Äì11" apart using uniform pressure
‚Ä¢	Tilt the knife bar to the required bevel angle using a calibrated protractor
‚Ä¢	Even ¬Ω¬∞ of bevel error can reduce chip quality and overload the machine
üìö BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 8-2-6
‚Ä¢ You grind in light passes:
‚Ä¢	No more than 0.002" per pass
‚Ä¢	Table feed speed: 60‚Äì80 FPM
‚Ä¢	Use constant coolant flow to avoid overheating
‚Ä¢	Monitor the knife face‚Äîblue tint or shiny finish = warning of heat damage
‚Ä¢ You hone the knife after grinding:
‚Ä¢	Use medium then fine honing stones, lightly oiled
‚Ä¢	Apply a circular or figure-8 motion along the bevel
‚Ä¢	Remove all wire edges and check under light for a clean, straight edge
‚Ä¢ You inspect and compare finished knives:
‚Ä¢	Verify the edge matches a known reference
‚Ä¢	Ensure no burrs, pits, or overheating marks are present
Knives and Chippers.critical:
Incorrect knife grinding causes: ‚Ä¢ Burned edges that lose temper
‚Ä¢ Bowed or chipped knives that vibrate or eject
‚Ä¢ Uneven chip thickness and poor product quality
‚Ä¢ Overload on motors and chipper disks
Skipping or rushing honing results in: ‚Ä¢ Wire edges that break off mid-cut
‚Ä¢ Irregular chipping
‚Ä¢ Damage to knife holders or anvils
Knife grinding is not just about sharpness‚Äîit‚Äôs about safety, uniformity, and chipper performance.

Knives and Chippers.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Grinder Maintenance and Setup
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Sections 8-2-2 to 8-2-5
‚Ä¢ Coolant System and Safety
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 8-2-2
‚Ä¢ Wheel Dressing and Truing
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Sections 8-2-3 to 8-2-4
Knives and Chippers.what: Grinders must be properly maintained to ensure even, accurate bevels and safe operation. Dull wheels, clogged coolant lines, or misaligned knife bars will damage knives‚Äîand can lead to serious injuries or equipment failure. You are responsible for the daily inspection, cleaning, and function testing of all knife grinding equipment.
Knives and Chippers.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ Before using the grinder:
‚Ä¢	You inspect wheel condition for cracks, glazing, or uneven wear
‚Ä¢	Perform a ring test on vitrified wheels to confirm integrity
‚Ä¢	Check that the wheel is trued and balanced
‚Ä¢	Confirm arbor flange tightness without overtorquing
üìö BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 8-2-4
‚Ä¢ You verify coolant system operation:
‚Ä¢	Flow is consistent and coolant level is adequate
‚Ä¢	Nozzles are aimed properly to cool the grinding zone
‚Ä¢	Coolant is mixed per manufacturer spec (usually 5‚Äì8% oil in water)
‚Ä¢ You dress grinding wheels regularly:
‚Ä¢	Use a diamond dresser or abrasive stick to expose new grit
‚Ä¢	Watch for signs of glazing, loading, or grooving
‚Ä¢ You inspect spindle and drive components:
‚Ä¢	Confirm no axial play or bearing vibration
‚Ä¢	Listen for motor strain or pulley misalignment
‚Ä¢ You clean grinder tables, guards, and magnetic bars after each session:
‚Ä¢	Remove filings and dust
‚Ä¢	Wipe surfaces and covers
‚Ä¢	Oil components as needed for smooth movement
Knives and Chippers.critical:
Grinders in poor condition cause: ‚Ä¢ Uneven bevels or overheating
‚Ä¢ Chatter marks and knife cracks
‚Ä¢ Incorrect clearance and knife projection
‚Ä¢ Inconsistent chip thickness and overload on chipper motors
Improper wheel maintenance also risks: ‚Ä¢ Explosive failure of vitrified wheels
‚Ä¢ Blade edge glazing
‚Ä¢ Machine downtime and unsafe working conditions
Routine grinder maintenance = consistent, safe, and efficient knife performance.

Knives and Chippers.text: Set clearances and other required measurements
Knives and Chippers.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Knife-to-Anvil Clearance and Adjustments
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Sections 8-1-8 to 8-1-9
‚Ä¢ Knife Length and Projection
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 8-1-7
‚Ä¢ Chipper Setup Checks
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 8-2-14
Knives and Chippers.what:
Clearances in chipper systems‚Äîespecially between the knife edge and chipper anvil‚Äîmust be set with precision to ensure clean shearing action, avoid overloading the disk, and maintain chip uniformity. Setting clearances also involves verifying knife projection, knife-to-knife length, and other critical measurements that affect chipper balance and performance.
This task demands proficiency with gauges, indicators, and manufacturer tolerances‚Äîapplied consistently across every knife in the disk.
Knives and Chippers.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ You measure knife-to-anvil clearance using a feeler gauge or dial indicator:
‚Ä¢	For most machines, acceptable clearance ranges from 0.030"‚Äì0.060"
‚Ä¢	You rotate the disk slowly and check clearance at each knife position
üìö BC Saw Filer Level 1, Sections 8-1-8 to 8-1-9
‚Ä¢ You measure knife projection (stick-out) using a projection gauge:
‚Ä¢	All knives in the disk must project equally
‚Ä¢	You adjust shims or backing screws to correct any offset
‚Ä¢ You confirm knife length uniformity:
‚Ä¢	Use a micrometer or caliper to ensure length differences are <0.005"
‚Ä¢	Unequal lengths create imbalance, vibration, and poor chip quality
‚Ä¢ You clean and inspect all knife pockets, holders, and chipper faces before measurement:
‚Ä¢	No debris, pitch, or corrosion can interfere with fit or reading accuracy
‚Ä¢ You document and compare results against machine or mill specification sheets
Knives and Chippers.critical:
Incorrect clearances and mismatched projection cause: ‚Ä¢ Imbalanced disk rotation and excessive wear on bearings
‚Ä¢ Poor chip formation (oversize, slivers, or fines)
‚Ä¢ Anvil and disk damage due to knife contact
‚Ä¢ Higher vibration, noise, and safety risk from knife ejection or fracture
Chipper clearances are directly tied to mill chip uniformity, machine longevity, and personnel safety. They must be checked and set with the same discipline as any saw setup.

Knives and Chippers.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Anvil and Knife Setup Principles
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Sections 8-1-8 and 8-2-14
‚Ä¢ Clearance Tools and Indicators
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 8-1-9
Knives and Chippers.what:
Anvil clearance refers to the distance between the cutting edge of the chipper knife and the face of the chipper anvil. This clearance must be measured precisely and adjusted using shims or set bolts. Inconsistent or incorrect anvil clearance affects chip size, causes knife fatigue, and can result in dangerous collisions between components.
This task ensures the chipper shears wood cleanly and efficiently, without overloading or damaging knives.
Knives and Chippers.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ You access the chipper with all lockout procedures applied
‚Ä¢ You clean the anvil face and surrounding surfaces:
‚Ä¢	Remove all pitch, dust, or metal fragments
‚Ä¢	Verify the anvil face is flat and undamaged
‚Ä¢ You rotate the disk slowly by hand and use a feeler gauge or dial indicator to measure the gap between the knife edge and the anvil:
‚Ä¢	Measure at several points across the knife edge
‚Ä¢	Record clearance values to check for taper or uneven spacing
‚Ä¢ If adjustments are needed, you:
‚Ä¢	Add or remove shims behind the knife
‚Ä¢	Turn set screws to bring the knife into the correct plane
‚Ä¢	Repeat the measurement process to confirm consistency
‚Ä¢ You verify that:
‚Ä¢	All knives have uniform clearance
‚Ä¢	The anvil face shows no scoring or wear lines that would affect future readings
Knives and Chippers.critical:
Too little clearance causes: ‚Ä¢ Knife-to-anvil collisions
‚Ä¢ Chipped knives and damaged anvils
‚Ä¢ Catastrophic failure of knife holders
Too much clearance causes: ‚Ä¢ Inconsistent chip size (thick/fines mix)
‚Ä¢ Overload on the cutting edge
‚Ä¢ Vibration and strain on chipper drive systems
Proper anvil clearance is essential to chipper safety and chip quality‚Äîand must be maintained on every knife installation.

Knives and Chippers.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Knife Runout Inspection
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 8-2-14
‚Ä¢ Disk Condition and Balancing
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 8-1-9
Knives and Chippers.what:
Runout refers to the lateral (side-to-side) or axial (in-and-out) movement of a rotating part‚Äîin this case, the chipper disk or knife path. Excessive runout creates vibration, noise, uneven chip formation, and dangerous stress on knife mounts and machine bearings.
As a saw filer, you must understand how to detect, measure, and diagnose both types of runout using precision tools, and how runout affects knife clearance, projection, and chip quality.
Knives and Chippers.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ You lock out the chipper and rotate the disk slowly by hand
‚Ä¢ You set up a dial indicator mounted to a fixed reference point (such as the chipper frame or mounting face):
‚Ä¢        For axial runout, place the indicator on the knife face or clamp
‚Ä¢        For lateral runout, place the indicator on the side of the disk or knife body
üìö BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 8-2-14
‚Ä¢ You record runout values by:
‚Ä¢        Zeroing the gauge
‚Ä¢        Rotating the disk one full revolution
‚Ä¢        Reading the total indicator movement (TIR ‚Äì Total Indicator Reading)
‚Ä¢ You compare values to acceptable tolerances (typically <0.005" axial, <0.002" lateral, unless otherwise specified by manufacturer)
‚Ä¢ You inspect mounting surfaces:
‚Ä¢        Disk faces must be clean, smooth, and free of corrosion or warping
‚Ä¢        Knife holders must be seated evenly‚Äîno burrs, metal shavings, or missing hardware
‚Ä¢ If runout exceeds tolerances, you:
‚Ä¢        Remove and re-seat knives or holders
‚Ä¢        Inspect and clean the disk hub, face, and mount bolts
‚Ä¢        Tag the machine for further service if structural issues (e.g., warped disk) are suspected
Other examples can be shafts, sharpener arbor, etc.
Knives and Chippers.critical:
Unchecked runout causes: ‚Ä¢ Knife-to-anvil misalignment
‚Ä¢ Uneven chip thickness and poor product recovery
‚Ä¢ Vibration that damages knife bolts, clamps, or disk faces
‚Ä¢ Knife cracking and potential ejection during operation
‚Ä¢ Long-term damage to chipper bearings and housings
Runout affects everything from knife safety to chip uniformity. Every filer must treat runout as a critical inspection point‚Äînot a minor defect.

Circular Saws.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Crack and Damage Limits
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Sections 9-1-1 to 9-1-2
‚Ä¢ Saw Retirement and Collar Zone Inspection
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 2-2-1
Circular Saws.what:
Every circular saw must be evaluated before service to determine if it can be safely repaired or if it must be permanently removed. This evaluation includes inspecting the plate, teeth, gullets, collar line, eye, and tension ring. Saw repairability depends on meeting strict visual and dimensional tolerances‚Äîespecially for crack length, plate damage, and eye elongation.
You are expected to perform this inspection independently and decide based on objective criteria‚Äînot just ‚Äúappearance.‚Äù
Circular Saws.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ You inspect the saw visually and with proper lighting:
‚Ä¢	Use backlighting or a flashlight under the plate to reveal dish, warp, or hairline cracks
‚Ä¢	Focus inspection around:
o	Gullets (stress points)
o	Collar line (common failure zone)
o	Eye and bolt holes (look for elongation or ovaling)
‚Ä¢ You use dye penetrant or marking fluid if needed to locate fine cracks
‚Ä¢ You check for:
‚Ä¢	Cracks exceeding allowable lengths
o	For example: in a 24‚Äì36" saw, a crack longer than 1¬Ω" in the collar zone requires removal from service
‚Ä¢	Warping or twist exceeding flatness spec (e.g. >0.006" runout is usually unacceptable)
‚Ä¢	Tension ring failure, missing drop, or visible tension imbalance
‚Ä¢	Eye elongation that prevents secure arbor fit
‚Ä¢ You reference WorkSafeBC Table 27-1 or shop-specific repairability criteria
‚Ä¢ You record your findings in the shop log or tag the saw accordingly:
‚Ä¢	"Serviceable"
‚Ä¢	"Send for weld and rebench"
‚Ä¢	"Scrap‚Äîexceeds safe limit"
Circular Saws.critical:
A damaged circular saw running at high RPM can: ‚Ä¢ Explode due to plate failure
‚Ä¢ Throw a tooth, clamp, or gullet segment
‚Ä¢ Cause severe personal injury or death
‚Ä¢ Lead to equipment damage, lumber defects, and unexpected downtime
This inspection is the first line of defense. If a saw goes back into service with hidden damage, it can fail catastrophically.

Circular Saws.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ ITCO Tooth Removal and Insertion
BC Saw Filer Level 2, Section 4-2-3
‚Ä¢ Bit and Shank Replacement
BC Saw Filer Level 2, Sections 4-1-9 to 4-1-11
Circular Saws.what:
üîß What this means:
Circular saw teeth wear over time from heat, abrasion, and impact. Depending on saw design, teeth may be bit-and-shank, inserted tooth (ITCO), or welded solid tip. Replacing worn or broken teeth involves safely removing the damaged part, cleaning the seating surface, and securing the new component with the correct tools and technique.
Tooth replacement requires careful alignment, correct seating, and the proper fit. Misaligned teeth can crack saw plates or fly off during operation.
Circular Saws.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ For Inserted Tooth (ITCO) saws:
‚Ä¢	Use a brass punch to drive out the old tooth
‚Ä¢	Clean the V-slot with a wire brush
‚Ä¢	Insert the correct left-hand or right-hand replacement tooth
‚Ä¢	Secure the new tooth with pins, rivets, or drive wedges, as required
üìö BC Saw Filer Level 2, Section 4-2-3
‚Ä¢ For Bit and Shank saws:
‚Ä¢	Use a removal wrench to back out the worn shank
‚Ä¢	Clean debris and carbon from the bore
‚Ä¢	Insert the replacement bit and shank, ensuring light friction fit
‚Ä¢	Final-seat using a hammer and dolly, with care to avoid over-tightening
‚Ä¢ During replacement:
‚Ä¢	You inspect tooth seating for gaps, twist, or over-insertion
‚Ä¢	Use a template or gauge to verify tooth height and projection match across the saw
‚Ä¢	You replace only with OEM or approved replacement teeth
‚Ä¢ After all replacements:
‚Ä¢	You rotate the saw to check for interference, runout, or seating error
‚Ä¢	You mark and log which teeth were changed and the reason
Circular Saws.critical:
Poor tooth replacement causes: ‚Ä¢ Tooth ejection under RPM
‚Ä¢ Vibration, imbalance, and tracking failure
‚Ä¢ Misalignment that damages the plate, gullets, or collar
Teeth are not just cutting edges‚Äîthey are part of the saw‚Äôs balance system. Precision in installation is essential for safe, long-running saws.

Circular Saws.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Crack Welding and Annealing
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Sections 9-7-3 to 9-7-6
‚Ä¢ Filler Metal and Torch Technique
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 9-5-4 to 9-5-5
Circular Saws.what:
When a saw develops cracks within allowable limits, it may be weld-repaired instead of being scrapped. You are expected to follow strict procedures for crack preparation, welding technique, filler selection, and post-weld treatment (annealing and peening) to ensure structural integrity is restored without introducing new stress.
Crack welding is not just a fabrication task‚Äîit‚Äôs a precision repair process that affects the saw‚Äôs strength, tension, and safety at full speed.
Circular Saws.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ You inspect the saw and identify all cracks:
‚Ä¢	Most cracks are located in gullets, collar zones, or plate edge
‚Ä¢	Cracks are marked, and any longer than spec (e.g. 1¬Ω" in collar zone) disqualify the saw from repair
üìö BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 2-2-1
‚Ä¢ You prepare the crack:
‚Ä¢	Drill a stress relief hole (1/8"‚Äì3/16") at the end of the crack to stop propagation
‚Ä¢	Bevel the crack edges using a small grinder or file (torch prep if required)
‚Ä¢ You select the correct welding method:
‚Ä¢	Use MIG, TIG, or oxy-acetylene, depending on saw thickness and shop standard
‚Ä¢	Choose correct filler: e.g., ER 70S-6 for MIG; high-carbon rod for oxy-acetylene
‚Ä¢	Maintain a neutral flame or low-voltage arc to avoid over-hardening
‚Ä¢ You control heat during the weld:
‚Ä¢	Use short weld segments to reduce heat input
‚Ä¢	Preheat saw to 300‚Äì400¬∞F if required to reduce hardening risk
‚Ä¢	After welding, perform annealing:
o	Bring the welded area to straw-to-blue color (~850‚Äì1200¬∞F) twice
o	Use temperature crayons or a color chart to confirm
‚Ä¢ After cooling:
‚Ä¢	Grind the weld flush with the saw plate
‚Ä¢	Inspect for porosity, shrinkage, or distortion
‚Ä¢	Peen the weld lightly on an anvil to relieve internal stress
‚Ä¢	Check for restored flatness and balance during benching
Circular Saws.critical:
Improper crack repair can lead to: ‚Ä¢ Rapid crack propagation and catastrophic failure
‚Ä¢ Welds that are too brittle or too soft
‚Ä¢ Loss of saw tension and tracking
‚Ä¢ Safety hazards from undetected heat zones or hard spots
Proper welding restores the saw‚Äôs structure while preserving critical characteristics like tension, balance, and gullet spacing. It must be done with maximum precision and post-weld verification.

Circular Saws.text: Operate topper, facer and side dresser
Circular Saws.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Top and Side Grinding Procedures
BC Saw Filer Level 2, Section 6-4-2
‚Ä¢ Tooth Geometry and Angle Setup
BC Saw Filer Level 2, Section 4-1-11
‚Ä¢ Profile Inspection and Grinding Defects
BC Saw Filer Level 2, Section 6-4-3
Circular Saws.what:
These three machines are used to grind and shape the geometry of circular saw teeth:
‚Ä¢	The topper grinds the top (bevel) of the tooth
‚Ä¢	The facer shapes the front (hook) face
‚Ä¢	The side dresser adjusts tooth width and side clearance
Correct operation ensures the saw cuts straight, maintains proper kerf, and runs safely under full load. Misuse or poor setup leads to premature wear, vibration, and cutting defects.
Circular Saws.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ You mount the saw to the grinder:
‚Ä¢	Secure saw on correct arbor with flat and concentric mounting
‚Ä¢	Remove any wobble before grinding
‚Ä¢	Use proper spacers and clamps to align the saw perfectly
‚Ä¢ On the topper, you:
‚Ä¢	Set the correct rake and bevel angles based on saw type and species
‚Ä¢	Use factory cam or adjustable cam profiles to match original tooth shape
‚Ä¢	Monitor wheel feed to remove consistent material (avoid under- or over-grind)
‚Ä¢ On the facer, you:
‚Ä¢	Grind the tooth face at the correct hook angle, usually 0¬∞ to 15¬∞
‚Ä¢	Ensure the wheel tracks square to the tooth body
‚Ä¢	Avoid creating notches or back grinding errors
‚Ä¢ On the side dresser, you:
‚Ä¢	Dress both left and right flanks of the tooth, removing 0.002"‚Äì0.004" per side
‚Ä¢	Maintain original tooth width and clearance
‚Ä¢	Use templates or micrometers to confirm uniformity
‚Ä¢ During the process:
‚Ä¢	You ensure coolant flow is constant, and the wheels are dressed and balanced
‚Ä¢	You inspect teeth regularly with a magnifier and reference template
‚Ä¢	After sharpening, you check for:
o	Consistent profile
o	Smooth finish (no grinder burns)
o	Equal tooth height and projection
Circular Saws.critical:
Incorrect grinding causes: ‚Ä¢ Irregular kerf and poor tracking
‚Ä¢ Heat cracks or burned cutting edges
‚Ä¢ Uneven cutting pressure, leading to blade wobble
‚Ä¢ Shortened saw life and unsafe operation
Top, face, and side grinding define the saw‚Äôs performance. Accurate grinding preserves geometry, prevents saw failure, and ensures clean, efficient cutting under production conditions.

Circular Saws.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Leveling and Tensioning Principles
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Sections 6-3-1 to 6-4-2
‚Ä¢ Drop Test and Tension Ring Evaluation
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 6-5-1
‚Ä¢ Saw Plate Straightening
BC Saw Filer Level 3, Section 11-2-1
Circular Saws.what:
üîß What this means:
Benching is the process of removing distortion (leveling) and introducing a controlled internal stress pattern (tensioning) to ensure the saw runs straight and stable at full operating speed. This is one of the most critical and skill-intensive tasks a filer performs.
You must be able to:
‚Ä¢	Identify and correct dish, humps, and ridges
‚Ä¢	Apply correct tension radius using hammers or stretcher rolls
‚Ä¢	Verify tension using proper gauges and techniques
‚Ä¢	Restore the saw‚Äôs ability to run flat at rest and true under RPM
Circular Saws.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ Leveling:
‚Ä¢	Place the saw on a certified leveling slab or plate
‚Ä¢	Use a straightedge and backlighting to detect bumps, humps, and dishing
‚Ä¢	Use a crowned leveling hammer and work in small overlapping strikes
‚Ä¢	Support the saw with the correct anvil radius and rotate between strikes to ensure uniformity
‚Ä¢	Check your progress frequently‚Äîstop when the plate is flat within 0.002" or less üìö BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 6-3-1 to 6-4-2
‚Ä¢ Tensioning:
‚Ä¢	Identify the correct tension radius, which depends on saw diameter, speed, and application
‚Ä¢	Apply tension using:
o	Tensioning hammer (for fine adjustment)
o	Stretcher roll (for large-scale tensioning)
‚Ä¢	Use a drop test or tension gauge to confirm proper stress pattern:
o	Tension ring should ‚Äúdrop‚Äù at the expected radius when lightly pressed with a back gauge
o	The ring must be concentric, not egg-shaped or offset
‚Ä¢ Final checks:
‚Ä¢	Flex the saw manually and verify it returns to shape
‚Ä¢	Inspect for uncorrected dish or signs of overworked areas
‚Ä¢	Confirm saw is balanced and tensioned for speed and load
Circular Saws.critical:
Improper benching leads to: ‚Ä¢ Wobbling and snaking saws
‚Ä¢ Kerf collapse and tracking failure
‚Ä¢ Premature saw failure or crack propagation
‚Ä¢ Excessive heat buildup and vibration
‚Ä¢ Dangerous saw instability at speed
A properly benched saw is safe, straight, and stable. This task defines the skill of a journeyperson filer and must be done with full attention to detail, patience, and precision.

Circular Saws.text: Operate and maintain saw shop equipment required for circular saw maintenance
Circular Saws.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Saw Shop Equipment Operation and Maintenance
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Sections 6-1-1 to 6-1-4
‚Ä¢ Grinder Setup and Coolant Use
BC Saw Filer Level 2, Section 4-1-11
‚Ä¢ Welding and Torch Safety
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 9-5-4 to 9-5-5
Circular Saws.what:
Filing room equipment must be accurately calibrated, safely operated, and routinely maintained to ensure safe and consistent circular saw servicing. This includes:
‚Ä¢	Grinders (top, face, side)
‚Ä¢	Welders and torches
‚Ä¢	Hammers and anvils
‚Ä¢	Tension gauges, drop testers, and straightedges
‚Ä¢	Collaring tools and cleaning systems
You are responsible for operating and caring for all of these tools according to manufacturer instructions and shop SOPs.
Circular Saws.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ Before use:
‚Ä¢	Inspect power tools for proper guards, switches, and RPM compatibility
‚Ä¢	Check grinding wheel condition (ring test, face condition, and dressing)
‚Ä¢	Confirm coolant flow, mixture, and nozzle direction
‚Ä¢ During use:
‚Ä¢	Use the correct flanges, mounts, and spacers for each saw and machine
‚Ä¢	Monitor for vibration, overheating, or chatter
‚Ä¢	Keep safety guards in place at all times‚Äînever bypass interlocks or covers
‚Ä¢ After use:
‚Ä¢	Clean grinding stations and tension tools
‚Ä¢	Drain or refill coolant systems as needed
‚Ä¢	Store tools properly (e.g., hammers on hooks, gauges in foam-lined drawers)
‚Ä¢ Regular maintenance includes:
‚Ä¢	Replacing worn belts, bearings, or grinding wheels
‚Ä¢	Lubricating sliding parts and adjusting set screws
‚Ä¢	Testing electrical systems and tagging out unsafe gear
‚Ä¢	Calibrating tension and drop gauges against known standards
‚Ä¢ You record maintenance tasks in a shop log or checklist
Circular Saws.critical:
Poorly maintained equipment leads to: ‚Ä¢ Inaccurate tensioning or grinding
‚Ä¢ Safety hazards from electrical faults or mechanical failures
‚Ä¢ Downtime due to tool unavailability or contamination
‚Ä¢ Inconsistent saw quality across shifts
Your equipment is your responsibility. The quality of your saw work is directly tied to the condition of the tools you use.

Band Saws.text: Properly swage teeth or replace Stellite inserts
Band Saws.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Swaging and Shaping Procedures
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Sections 7-3-1 to 7-3-27
‚Ä¢ Stellite Tip Removal and Welding
BC Saw Filer Level 2, Sections 6-2-3 to 6-4-1
Band Saws.what:
Band saw teeth must be prepared with the correct cutting width and clearance to ensure straight cuts, stable tracking, and efficient chip removal. This is achieved by either swaging (cold-forming the tooth tip) or replacing Stellite inserts (hard-surfaced tips brazed to the saw).
Each method demands careful setup, accurate geometry, and clean finishing‚Äîdone without overstressing the tooth or deforming the saw body.
Band Saws.looksLike:
For Swaged Teeth: ‚Ä¢ You identify the correct saw gauge and tooth spacing before setup
‚Ä¢ Use a manual hand swage, air swage, or automatic swage/shaper depending on shop equipment
‚Ä¢ Set the side die spacing based on species and saw gauge (refer to mill guidelines)
‚Ä¢ Apply steady pressure (air swage set to 60‚Äì80 psi) to cold-form the tip outward
‚Ä¢ Use the shaper to:
‚Ä¢	Restore radial clearance
‚Ä¢	Create tangential back taper
‚Ä¢	Refine kerf to specification (¬±0.002")
For Stellite Inserts: ‚Ä¢ Inspect tip for wear: if it‚Äôs worn past 50% of height or chipped, it must be replaced
‚Ä¢ Remove worn tip using a light oxy-acetylene torch:
‚Ä¢	Apply neutral flame
‚Ä¢	Use brass brush to sweep away silver solder
‚Ä¢ Clean tip seat and prepare the surface for new insert
‚Ä¢ Align insert to correct projection, square to gullet and saw back
‚Ä¢ Re-weld using silver solder and neutral flame
‚Ä¢ Inspect for alignment, overhang, and complete bond
Band Saws.critical:
‚Ä¢ Improper swaging causes:
‚Ä¢	Overworked saws
‚Ä¢	Irregular kerf and tracking problems
‚Ä¢	Increased vibration and heat cracks
‚Ä¢ Improper tipping causes:
‚Ä¢	Tooth ejection under load
‚Ä¢	Uneven side clearance and saw snaking
‚Ä¢	Burned tips that prematurely dull
Correctly prepared cutting teeth = safe sawing, efficient feed rates, and long saw life.

Band Saws.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Tooth Alignment Procedures
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 7-2-6
Band Saws.what:
Tooth alignment refers to the position, height, and angular accuracy of each tooth on the saw. Poor alignment results in:
‚Ä¢	Irregular cutting load
‚Ä¢	Saw vibration
‚Ä¢	Premature wear and uneven tooth grinding
As a filer, you must inspect, correct, and confirm alignment using gauges and hand tools‚Äîespecially before tensioning or grinding.
Band Saws.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ You use a tooth alignment gauge (with or without a dial indicator):
‚Ä¢	Place the gauge on the saw and advance tooth by tooth
‚Ä¢	Identify teeth that are bent, tipped forward/backward, or twisted
‚Ä¢ For minor misalignment:
‚Ä¢	Use a set wrench to bend the tooth carefully back to neutral
‚Ä¢	Apply pressure slowly and deliberately‚Äîdon‚Äôt overstress the root
‚Ä¢ For major misalignment or spring-back:
‚Ä¢	Bend slightly past center to relieve stress
‚Ä¢	Re-check after a few teeth to ensure correction holds
‚Ä¢ You inspect again after grinding or saw flipping:
‚Ä¢	Ensure no teeth shifted due to wheel pressure or saw stress
‚Ä¢ Alignment must be done after leveling and before tensioning
Band Saws.critical:
‚Ä¢ Misaligned teeth cause:
‚Ä¢	Vibration and snaking cuts
‚Ä¢	Uneven wear and gullet cracking
‚Ä¢	Poor tracking and reduced tension performance
‚Ä¢ Ignoring this step can ruin all other setup work
Tooth alignment directly impacts saw performance, noise, feed rate, and safety. Precision here prevents cascading issues downstream.

Band Saws.text: Grind teeth to proper geometry and regrind gullets as required
Band Saws.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Tooth and Gullet Grinding
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Sections 7-4-15 to 7-4-18
‚Ä¢ Sliver Tooth Grinding Techniques
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Sections 13-3-3 to 13-3-4
Band Saws.what:
Band saw tooth geometry directly affects chip removal, feed rate, saw tracking, and cut quality. You are expected to restore worn or swaged teeth to their correct hook angle, gullet depth, and clearance geometry using the proper grinding wheels and techniques.
This task also includes regrinding gullets, which must be maintained to the correct shape and depth to prevent fatigue and cracking.
Band Saws.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ You determine tooth form (e.g., straight, sliver, hooked) and select the correct:
‚Ä¢	Grinding cam profile
‚Ä¢	Tooth template or sample
‚Ä¢	Grinding wheel (CBN for Stellite; vitrified for swaged steel)
‚Ä¢ You perform profile grinding or top-and-face grinding:
‚Ä¢	Profile grinding replicates the full tooth shape using a cam
‚Ä¢	Top-and-face grinding targets wear zones only
‚Ä¢ You set angles according to saw design:
‚Ä¢	Hook angle, typically between 0¬∞ and 30¬∞
‚Ä¢	Back clearance and face clearance verified with a protractor or template
‚Ä¢ You maintain correct gullet shape:
‚Ä¢	Avoid flat-bottom gullets or undercutting the root
‚Ä¢	Use a gullet radius suitable for tooth pitch and species (larger gullets for frozen or knotty wood)
‚Ä¢ You use light feeds and inspect for:
‚Ä¢	Burns or blue tint on tooth faces
‚Ä¢	Tooth length uniformity
‚Ä¢	Gullet symmetry across the saw
‚Ä¢ You inspect after grinding using:
‚Ä¢	Magnifier or template overlay
‚Ä¢	Dial indicator if checking height consistency
Band Saws.critical:
Improper grinding leads to: ‚Ä¢ Uneven cutting pressure and saw drift
‚Ä¢ Excessive gullet stress ‚Üí cracks
‚Ä¢ Loss of kerf or burn lines in lumber
‚Ä¢ Shortened saw life due to chipped or deformed teeth
Correct geometry ensures:
‚Ä¢	Balanced cutting
‚Ä¢	Efficient chip flow
‚Ä¢	Safer operation under tension and feed pressure

Band Saws.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Crack Detection and Weld Procedure
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Sections 9-7-3 to 9-7-6
‚Ä¢ Peening and Strain Relief
BC Saw Filer Level 3, Section 5-4-7
‚Ä¢ Crack Inspection Tolerances
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 6-8-2
Band Saws.what:
Tooth breakage and cracks in bandsaws must be repaired using proper welding, crack stop drilling, and post-weld stress relief. These repairs restore tooth integrity and prevent cracks from spreading across the plate.
You must know how to identify weldable vs. scrap damage, prepare and weld properly, and peen or grind the area to restore balance and safety.
Band Saws.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ You inspect damaged areas using:
‚Ä¢	Backlighting or flashlight
‚Ä¢	Magnifier for surface fractures
‚Ä¢	Dye penetrant for hairline cracks
‚Ä¢ For minor cracks:
‚Ä¢	Drill a stress relief hole at the end of the crack
‚Ä¢	Bevel crack edges slightly for weld penetration
‚Ä¢	Weld using:
o	MIG or TIG for steel
o	Oxy-acetylene for fine control on thin plates
‚Ä¢ For tooth repairs:
‚Ä¢	Remove fractured or deformed tooth material
‚Ä¢	Weld a build-up that matches the original tooth profile
‚Ä¢	Regrind to match tooth geometry
‚Ä¢ After welding:
‚Ä¢	Peen the repair using a small crowned hammer to relieve stress
‚Ä¢	Grind flush to plate or tooth face
‚Ä¢	Inspect for porosity, pits, or incomplete fusion
‚Ä¢	Level and tension the area before saw goes back into service
Band Saws.critical:
Unrepaired or poorly welded cracks: ‚Ä¢ Spread quickly under feed strain and heat
‚Ä¢ Lead to catastrophic failure (snapping or exploding blades)
‚Ä¢ Cause inconsistent tension and poor cut quality
Weld repairs extend saw life, reduce replacement costs, and prevent safety incidents‚Äîbut only when done with precision and stress control.

Band Saws.text: Explain and demonstrate proper leveling of band saw
Band Saws.referenceCode:
‚Ä¢ Leveling Techniques and Inspection
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 13-1-1
‚Ä¢ Back Maintenance and Plate Prep
BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 13-1-2
Band Saws.what:
Leveling is the process of removing twist, humps, dish, and other distortions from a bandsaw plate to restore flatness. This is a foundational benching skill and must be performed before any tensioning. A perfectly leveled saw ensures that the blade runs quietly, tracks properly, and doesn‚Äôt develop cracks or heat stress under speed.
Leveling requires the ability to detect surface irregularities under 0.002" and correct them using proper hammer technique and anvil setup.
Band Saws.looksLike:
‚Ä¢ You place the saw on a certified leveling slab:
‚Ä¢	Plate must be clean and free of oil, chips, or pitch
‚Ä¢	You verify that slab surface is dead-flat using a calibrated straightedge
‚Ä¢ You use a bright inspection light and a straightedge to:
‚Ä¢	Detect high spots, ridges, twist, and dish
‚Ä¢	Sweep multiple zones: edge, gullet line, mid-body, and back
üìö BC Saw Filer Level 1, Section 13-1-1
‚Ä¢ You select the correct crowned leveling hammer:
‚Ä¢	Light hammer for fine work
‚Ä¢	Heavier hammer for severe dish or warp
‚Ä¢ While leveling:
‚Ä¢	You always strike across the long axis of the bump or ridge
